Prior to my PhD, I have interned at the Bosch Center for AI and worked on explanation methods in computer vision and co-authored the paper ‚ÄúInterpretable and fine-grained visual explanations for convolutional neural networks‚Äù.
In addition to my academic pursuits, I am passionate about addressing the societal dimensions of AI. I have co-authored the book ‚ÄúWie Machinen lernen‚Äù to make machine learning accessible to a wide audience and actively engage in teaching computer science to both elementary and high school students through initiatives like ‚ÄúKI macht Schule‚Äù. I firmly believe in the importance of introducing young learners to contemporary computer science topics from an early age.
Before I forget: To be anonymous, go generic. In the English language, ‚ÄúJohn Doe‚Äù is about as generic as it gets. Now, as I am German I considered the pendant ‚ÄúMax Musterman‚Äù. Strip away the vowels and you have it: MxMstrmn.

summary: We introduce MAGNet, a novel graph-based model for molecule generation that uses abstract shapes before generating atom and bond types, addressing limitations in existing methods and creating molecules with more diverse topological structures and atom/bond assignments.
title: MAGNet: Motif-Agnostic Generation of Molecules from Shapes

summary: The compositional perturbation autoencoder (CPA) is a deep learning model for predicting the transcriptomic responses of single cells to single or combinatorial treatments from drugs and genetic manipulations.
title: Predicting cellular responses to complex perturbations in high‚Äêthroughput screens

summary: We explore the impact of subgraph structures and vocabulary design on distribution learning for small drug molecules, aditionally, introducing a new method "Subcover" which improves upon existing approaches.
title: The power of motifs as inductive bias for learning molecular distributions

summary: We present a model which enables counterfactual response predictions for unseen drugs and evaluate how large scale bulk RNA-seq datasets can be leveraged to improve generalisation performance on single-cell data.
title: Predicting Cellular Responses to Novel Drug Perturbations at a Single-Cell Resolution

summary: Graphs capture many phenomena in single-cell genomics, ranging from similarity and proximity of cells to gene networks. We discuss recent advances and the theory behing in graph representation learning as well as its application to single-cell genomics.
title: Graph representation learning for single-cell biology
